node.title: Error while updating MOOSE
node.bodyText:
My moose was working fine until I tried to update it today. Below is the error I get
python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 belson]$ cd ~/projects/moose
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 moose]$ 
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 moose]$ git fetch origin
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 moose]$ 
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 moose]$ git rebase origin/master
Cannot rebase: You have unstaged changes.
Please commit or stash them.
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 moose]$ cd ~/projects/belson
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 belson]$ make -j 6
Not compiling MOOSE with NEML2 because NEML2_DIR is not a valid NEML2 checkout and/or libtorch is not enabled.
***ERROR***
WASP does not seem to be available.
Make sure to either run scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh in your MOOSE directory,
or set WASP_DIR to a valid WASP install
make: *** [wasp_submodule_status] Error 1
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 belson]$ ./run_tests -j 6
Building and linking hit...
/home/emmanuel324/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit/parse.cc: In member function ‘hit::Field::Kind hit::Field::kind()’:
/home/emmanuel324/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit/parse.cc:684:34: error: ‘class wasp::HITNodeView’ has no member named ‘token_type’; did you mean 
‘set_type’?
  684 |     auto token_type = value_node.token_type();
      |                                  ^~~~~~~~~~
      |                                  set_type
make: *** [hit] Error 1
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/emmanuel324/projects/moose/python/pyhit/__init__.py", line 13, in <module>
    import hit
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'hit'
During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/emmanuel324/projects/moose/python/pyhit/__init__.py", line 18, in <module>
    import hit
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'hit'
During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/emmanuel324/projects/belson/./run_tests", line 11, in <module>
    from TestHarness import TestHarness
  File "/home/emmanuel324/projects/moose/python/TestHarness/__init__.py", line 15, in <module>
    from .TestHarness import TestHarness
  File "/home/emmanuel324/projects/moose/python/TestHarness/TestHarness.py", line 20, in <module>
    from FactorySystem.Factory import Factory
  File "/home/emmanuel324/projects/moose/python/FactorySystem/__init__.py", line 13, in <module>
    from .Parser import Parser
  File "/home/emmanuel324/projects/moose/python/FactorySystem/Parser.py", line 13, in <module>
    import pyhit
  File "/home/emmanuel324/projects/moose/python/pyhit/__init__.py", line 22, in <module>
    import hit
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'hit'
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 belson]$

Hello
A few things here:

did you update the moose packages on conda? (conda update moose-libmesh)
your rebase failed. Can you commit all your changes then try again?

This is what i used. And how do I commit my changes?
cd ~/projects/moose
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/master

after git rebase origin/master you see it fail
do this:
git commit -am "My changes"
Should I try updating the moose again.
yeah once you have commited you can update libmesh first then rebase your branch of moose
the command i replace with "My changes", is it the directory containing the changes?

All the changes I made are in my own application
This is the result I am getting trying to commit
git: 'clang-format' is not a git command. See 'git --help'.
Your code is not properly formatted.
Run git clang-format to resolve the following issues:
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 step01_diffusion]$ git commit -am "problems"
git: 'clang-format' is not a git command. See 'git --help'.
Your code is not properly formatted.
Run git clang-format to resolve the following issues:
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 step01_diffusion]$

All the changes I made are in my own application
This is the result I am getting trying to commit
git: 'clang-format' is not a git command. See 'git --help'.
Your code is not properly formatted.
Run git clang-format to resolve the following issues:
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 step01_diffusion]$ git commit -am "problems"
git: 'clang-format' is not a git command. See 'git --help'.
Your code is not properly formatted.
Run git clang-format to resolve the following issues:
(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 step01_diffusion]$

This looks like a problem with your git hooks.
Maybe you should activate the moose conda environment?
How do I activate the moose conda environment?
conda activate moose

(python-stack) [emmanuel324@tinkercliffs1 ~]$ conda activate moose
EnvironmentNameNotFound: Could not find conda environment: moose
You can list all discoverable environments with conda info --envs.
how did you install moose? which instructions did you follow?
I actually followed instructions from someone from Moose because I was finding it difficult to get a current cmake to load my environment. I want to see if I can find the thread

node.title: InterfaceKernel for ArrayVariable
node.bodyText:
Hi,
This is a general question regarding mooseframework. Not a bug or an issue.
The problem that I am working on needs to develop an InterfaceKernel for ArrayVariable, because the model has many solution variables. Those variables can be grouped in few of the ArrayVariables.
During implementation I observed that,
In most of the base classes (KernelBase.h, DGKernelBase.h, NodalBCBase.h ) resudual and jacobian related functions at QP (e.g., computeQpResidual, computeQpJacobian, computeQpOffDiagJacobian) are not declared in their corresponding base classes. Rather they are declared in the next level of derived classes (Kernel.h. ArrayKernel.h,    DGKernel.h, ArrayDGKernel.h  etc). This is good because those classes need to inherit common stuff(element, neighbor, QP etc) from their base class([kernel, Arraykernel]<= KernelBase, [DGKernel, ArrayDGKernel]<=DGKernelBase etc.). And computeQpResidual, computeQpJacobian, computeQpOffDiagJacobian can have different return types based on the variable type(real, array) they are operating on.
One exception is in the InterfaceKernelBase.h. Where computeQpJacobian, computeQpOffDiagJacobian are declared in the base class itself, with a return type 'Real'. I was wondering if there is any reason for doing that?
Because, when I write the class ArrayInterfaceKernel.h derived from  InterfaceKernelBase.h for ArrayVariable, return type mismatch for computeQpJacobian and computeQpOffDiagJacobian prohibits to inherit(and override) those two functions from that base class.

  
    
      moose/framework/include/interfacekernels/InterfaceKernelBase.h
    
    
        Lines 46 to 54
      in
      27c9045
    
  
  
    

        
          
           protected: 
        

        
          
             /// Compute jacobians at quadrature points 
        

        
          
             virtual Real computeQpJacobian(Moose::DGJacobianType /*type*/) { return 0; } 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
             /// compute off-diagonal jacobian components at quadrature points 
        

        
          
             virtual Real computeQpOffDiagJacobian(Moose::DGJacobianType /*type*/, unsigned int /*jvar*/) 
        

        
          
             { 
        

        
          
               return 0; 
        

        
          
             } 
        
    
  


Best
Subhendu Chakraborty
Los Alamos National Laboratory

I did not check the code, but we probably did not think of array variables when developing InterfaceKernelBase. Thanks for working on this! I created an issue #26268 for this at the end of last year for your information.
This sounds right. Array variables were a later addition and interface kernels are also a rarer need

node.title: Applying volumetric constraint in phase field model for whole domain
node.bodyText:
Hello
I am trying to model the phase-field variable eta which evolves due to electroplating at a constant current density. I have built the kernels for eta. However, I want an external constraint as follow:
volume integral(d eta/ dt)dV = Constant (which signifies the volume integral of change is order parameter w.r.t time is constant as total current is held constant )
How do I implement such constraint in moose?
Thanks

Hello
Have you looked the Constraints system?
Or can you formulate the constraint as a Bound on a variable (with the Bounds system)? THat's also an option
Guillaume

yes I looked into constraint systems. However, I found some discussion on this at
https://groups.google.com/g/moose-users/c/7u7z51mZ3xE
The constraint I am trying to apply is not localized for an element but is the volumetric integral over whole simulation box. As per the discussion in the above link I came across ScalarLagrangeMultiplier
But again I am confused whether this constraint is per element or for the whole simulation domain.
Thanks
My PDE looks like this

and constraint

here Ir is constant

Are c_s, F, S and xi variables? And Ir is a known constant?
I think we can apply this constraint with a lagrange multiplier otherwise, using a scalar kernel.
It's been done with this scalar kernel for the average
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/scalarkernels/AverageValueConstraint.html
it could be adapted for any integral

node.title: problem with Splitting mesh file
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Experts
I have splited my mesh file into 128 chunks and trying to run my input file but its showing the following error. How can I solve this problem?
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "mixing_len_aux_ker", of type "WallDistanceMixingLengthAux".
WallDistanceMixingLengthAux only supports replicated meshes

Hello
So either stop using distributed meshes.
OR
You ll need to use the WallDistanceMixingLengthAux in a simple simulation with no flow and no distributed mesh.
Save the output in a checkpoint file preferrably or an exodus file
In your real distributed simulation, do not use the  WallDistanceMixingLengthAux, instead load the output field from the checkpoint/exodus file

node.title: Inviscid flow an free slip BC
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I am trying to run inviscid flow simulations, to later use as an initial condition for the viscous case in the FE INS module.
However, I have not found a way to implement a free slip/no penetration boundary condition for my geometry - in this case, an aerofoil.
I had thought that a Neumann BC of zero for all velocity components at the boundary would do the trick, and attempted to implement this using 'ADVectorFunctionBC'.
However, the solution for this was the same as my initial condition (constant velocity for the whole domain), with the flow not moving around the obstacle. The outlet boundary condition was constant pressure = 0.
I came across this thread when looking for a solution: #21418
However, I am having trouble understanding the difference between the 'no flux' and 'no penetration' cases described here, as well where the mentioned approaches are implemented (ie - can this be done through a moose input file, or would custom BCs be required?)
My question then, is: Have I misunderstood the relationship between Neumann BCs and the no penetration condition, and what is the proper way to implement the free slip condition for inviscid flows in FE, rather than FV?
Thanks!

Hello
Are the flow variables defined inside the aerofoil as well?
In other words, is the aerofoil boundary inside the flow domain or well on the boundary?
Which variable set are you using (velocities or momentum?) ? For whether we have it or not
Guillaume

The flow variables are not defined in the aerofoil, no. Does this mean that not specifying any boundary condition is the same as what I've manually implemented by setting a Neumann BC to zero?
I'm not certain what you mean by 'variable set', so to be clear, I'm solving for velocity (as well as pressure), which is a Lagrange vector type, but the kernels are 'INSADMomentumAdvection', 'INSADMomentumViscous', and so on.
Thanks!

Whether having no BC is equivalent to a 'no-penetration' depends on the equation. It is often equivalent to 'no flux' to have a 0 contribution to the residual at the boundary for balance equations.
For INSAD, the no-BC or no-penetration boundary condition is the INSADMomentumNoBCBC.
I asked about the variable set because the flow equations can be solved with P, v, T or with the conservative variable set rho, momentum, energy,

Okay... I think I'm having trouble understanding what the 'no BC' BC is doing to achieve no penetration.
The description to me sounds like it is reducing the error compared to a Neumann BC of zero when dealing with outflow boundaries, whereas I don't want any flow passing through my boundary at all.
In terms of the velocity variable, I believe I'm after u dot n = 0.
Where u is the velocity vector and n is normal to the boundary.
I think I've convinced myself that this can't be achieved using Neumann BC's imposed on the velocity variable, since this would still allow constant flow through the boundary. Previously I was visualising mass flux, hence my misunderstanding.
Is INSADMomentumNoBCBC still appropriate to impose the above condition?
(As a side note if so, is there a convenient way to pass in components of my velocity variable, since the BC does not accept vectors? If not, I can tweak the code to do so.)
Hopefully what I want to achieve makes sense - thanks again for your help!
The convection term is not integrated by parts in the FE implementation (at least currently) and so any integrated boundary condition you set will have no impact on the convection "flux"
Isnt a 'natural' boundary condition a slip one though? I feel like the 'unnatural', eg the one that you have to do more work for, is setting velocity to 0 for no-slip ?

The natural boundary condition will set stresses to 0 and that's it. You are used to FV where we convert the advection term into a face term. In the current FE implementation we don't integrate the advection term by parts and so it doesn't appear in surface terms, e.g. integrated boundary conditions
Thanks both for the clarification, and great to hear there's something on the way!
Hi, I would like to know if there is any further update on the free slip BC? Looks like MomentumFreeSlipBC was implemented for 2D only. Is there a similar method for 3D?

node.title: How to get a node location and

node.bodyText:
Hello
I believe this is already implemented.
You can use these two objects:

parsedMaterial to turn the variable into a material property then
a RadialAverage to compute the average
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/RadialAverage.html

OR you can use this mesh division:

CylindricalGridDivision to number the mesh https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshdivisions/CylindricalGridDivision.html
and this vector postprocessor to get a reduction using this numbering
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/MeshDivisionFunctorReductionVectorPostprocessor.html

From those options, I think the first one may work better for me, however, when I tried to run the input with it I had the error:
A 'RadialAverage' is not a registered object.

If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically linked library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.

I think this object is only present in a single module. Probably thermal_hydraulics.
maybe try the second option

I just needed to update my MOOSE. Now, I can use the RadialAverage 😅
However, now I have two questions about it:
1- Does it calculate the same average for the whole block? (I need it for each axial position, in this case, it could be for each axial division of the mesh)
2- How can I retrieve the calculated value on the source code of my model and, if possible, on the input? For this last one, I looked on postprocessors and vectorpostprocessors and did not find any.

node.title: Cannot run on parallel in a local HPC
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I have been using a moose based FEM package on moose without no problem; however, after i added a new auxiliary variable that calculate the plastic deformation, I get the following error whenever I am truing to run it on parallel. I was wondering if you could help me figure this out.

(moose) s_vadiee@speed-32:/nfs/speed-scratch/s_vadiee/September/00-Dip45-base-case/ICs$ mpiexec -n 32 //speed-scratch/s_vadiee/opt/golem/golem-opt -i 05-THM-Plastic-Slip-3000m.i

Mesh:

  Mesh Dimension:          3

    Total:                 119732

    Min/Max/Avg:           3154/4344/3741

Auxiliary System:
  Num DOFs:                26639633
  Num Local DOFs:          837932
  Variables:               { "stress_xx" "stress_yy" "stress_zz" "stress_xy" "stress_xz" ... "strain_yy" 
                             "strain_zz" "strain_xy" "strain_xz" "strain_yz" } { "vf_x" "vf_y" "vf_z"

Currently Executing

    Setting Up Materials
      Finished Computing Initial Material Values                                         [  0.71 s] [  899 MB]
    Finished Setting Up Materials                                                        [  0.71 s] [  899 MB]
    Building SemiLocalElemMap....                                                        [ 31.18 s] [  938 MB]
  Finished Performing Initial Setup                                                      [ 34.08 s] [  938 MB]

Time Step 0, time = 0
ime Step 1, time = 1, dt = 1

===================================================================================
=   BAD TERMINATION OF ONE OF YOUR APPLICATION PROCESSES
=   PID 16449 RUNNING AT speed-32.encs.concordia.ca
=   EXIT CODE: 11
=   CLEANING UP REMAINING PROCESSES
=   YOU CAN IGNORE THE BELOW CLEANUP MESSAGES
===================================================================================
YOUR APPLICATION TERMINATED WITH THE EXIT STRING: Segmentation fault (signal 11)
This typically refers to a problem with your application.
Please see the FAQ page for debugging suggestions

Hello
This is a genuine bug, signal 11 means we're reading out of bounds most likely
Could you please share your input with us? A git repo works best for us.
Alternatively if you want to look for it yourself, seg faults are easy to find using a debugger
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html
Guillaume

Yes, here is the link to my input file
https://github.com/saeedvdi/GeoSaslatoon_Conference.git
And this runs with Golem?
Yes

looks like I need your mesh to run this input.
If you cant share your mesh do you mind making a dummy mesh with the same block / boundary names.
Using these generators for example
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/CartesianMeshGenerator.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/StitchedMeshGenerator.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/RenameBoundaryGenerator.html

I have uploaded the mesh in the same git repository.
Thank you in advance for your assistance.

looks to be a ghosting issue, that s what I get compiling in devel mode

    Computing Initial Residual
      Computing Residual.libMesh terminating:
No index 1948079 in ghosted vector.
Vector contains [3297537,6592620)
And empty ghost array.

EDIT: still looking for the object causing this

seems this object and the two below are involved.
  [normal_stress]
    type = GolemFaultNormalStress
    variable = normal_stress
    boundary = '9'
    check_boundary_restricted = false
  []

Boundary restricted auxkernels can be a little harder to get right. Do people usually use this with a boundary restriction?
Internal to the mesh or external?
It looks internal in your mesh

It's kind of hacky but all you need is to add a layer of ghosting to avoid the error (I havent checked the results)
To do that, just use an object that lets you add that. For example,
[AuxKernels]
  [add_ghosting]
    type = ProjectionAux
    variable = dummy
    v = yield
    ghost_layers = 1
    execute_on = 'NONE'
    block = 1
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [dummy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

It would be great to engage with the Golem developers to discuss why they need ghosting on these 3 boundary-restricted auxkernels. Maybe it s simply that to compute the stress, one needs the neighbor values to form a derivative

Hi,
According to the response of @GiudGiud meaning that you have problem in "normal stress" block.
Actually I am working on such problems (simulation) as well.  So I wrote auxkernels for computing stress on such condition (e.g. computing stress on fault in deep reservoir modeling). I will do "pull request" to add i them on MOOSE soon.
@GiudGiud I was able to figure out the problem, and now I can run it in parallel. You can close the discussion. And thank you for your help

node.title: gravity magnitude jumps around sidesets and lower dimensional block
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am working on thermo-hydro-mechanical geothermal reservoir simulation, I want to model the response of a fault against water injection. To model the 2D fault i have to option 1) defining fault as a physical entity using Gmsh along with "lower_dimensional_block" and 2) defining fault as a lower dimensional block using MOOSE options (i.e.  SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator and LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator). So, the input file for both is the same only mesh block changes.
the model has 15-15-6 km dimension in x,y and z direction and the fault located at the center. Accoring to the manual of "EquelValueConstraint" LINK , I defined two sidessets on the boundaries of the subdomains at two sides of the fault as follows:
[Mesh]
  [./file]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = tpv104-inbox-fault.msh
  [../]
  [./sidesetmid1]
    type = SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator
    input = 'file'
    primary_block = 'SDMidBack'
    paired_block = 'SDMidFront'
    new_boundary = 'primary1_interface'
  [../]
  [./sidesetmid2]
    type = SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator
    input = 'sidesetmid1'
    primary_block = 'SDMidFront'
    paired_block = 'SDMidBack'
    new_boundary = 'primary2_interface'
  [../]
  [interfacemid]
    type = LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator
    input = sidesetmid2
    sidesets = 'primary2_interface'
    new_block_id = '10000'
    new_block_name = 'interfacemid'
    []
    []

Here is the model (figure 1):

When I am using the first technique (adding "lower_dimensional_block" phrase in .msh mesh file), everything is fine and the outputs make sense.
However, I have to use second technique as I need to have "EqualValueConstraint" in my simulation meaning that I have to have sidesets and LDBlock in the mesh. So, I defined then as above. At this step, I only defined gravity in the model. But the stress distribution along depth seems wrong. in the following, more detials are given:
According to Mechanics, I tried to set gravity and I applied it using two methods available in Porous Flow including : Gravity Kernel and Action. I drew a line crossing the center of the model from top to bottom to check gravity distribution over depth. But at the bottom of the fault I have got strange jump in gravity (figure below, figure 2) at two scenarios, kernel and action:

Also, as you can see, displacement seems strange as well, i.e. lower dimensional block OR sidesets behave like sink where the magnitude differs alot w.r.t. around.
Just to make a comparisson, i plotted the distribution at a point far away from the lower dimensional block and sidesets. It is a bit shocking, since the jump disappears. Also, comparing this figure with the figure above (figure 2), it can be see that the gravity magnitude changes at the top alot. in this figure, the magnitude starts from about zero which makes sense BUT in the figure above it starts from positive and drops suddenly to negative magnitude.

To delve more into the issue, i clipped the model at the center where fault exsits to see the distribution. It is obvious that the magnitude along the fault changes alot (and does not make sense).

I can not understand what is happening once lower dimensional block OR sidesets are working with 3D elements. How can i solve this issue?
BTW, I got the almsot same result for the gravity distribution when I set hydrostatic stress state in the model, Sxx=Syy=Szz.
Thank you in advance

Hello
I wonder if the gravity kernel is not applied on all the elements it should. That could cause artificial stress.
@1runer thoughts?
Guillaume

Hi,
@GiudGiud  and @cpgr
I thought, the issue comes from my mesh or input file etc, so I tried one of the tests from MOOSE which has lower dimensional block((modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/j_integral/j_integral_2d_block_restrict.i)), without any edit in input file I just plot the stress along a line, the following show stress-xx and stress-yy along a line:


So, as you can see the jump shows up on lower dimensional block in this example either stress-xx or stress-yy as well.
why such jump happens?
Thanks in advance
Rahim
I wonder if it is just an output artefact that the stress auxvariables aren't projected to the lower dimensional block?

I would expect a 0 in that case
@roystgnr do you know what we do for lower D variable output
In the example just above the spikes do go to zero, which is why I suspect an output artefact. I wonder if it is a bit different to the first example.

I wrote some hacky code to allow users to optionally output fake lower-D elements on which to output SIDE_HIERARCHIC variables when using that FE type ... but we're not using fake visualization-only elements here, right?  We're creating actual, part-of-the-mesh-and-assembly lower-D elements.  AFAIK at the libMesh level we don't try to do any sort of projection from higher-D to lower-D elements when we output the latter, we simply output only those variables which are active on that subdomain.
So ... are stress-xx and stress-yy active variables on the lower-D elements?  Do we have something trying to postprocess them that's assuming it's only getting called on a higher-D element?

I wonder if it is just an output artefact that the stress auxvariables aren't projected to the lower dimensional block?

Thanks @cpgr
The issue is not only related to stress projection, also as you can see the displacement behavior sounds inaccurate as well. Actually, the lower dimension at the center moves down more or less "independently" resuting in high displacement zone at the center.

I wrote some hacky code to allow users to optionally output fake lower-D elements on which to output SIDE_HIERARCHIC variables when using that FE type ... but we're not using fake visualization-only elements here, right? We're creating actual, part-of-the-mesh-and-assembly lower-D elements. AFAIK at the libMesh level we don't try to do any sort of projection from higher-D to lower-D elements when we output the latter, we simply output only those variables which are active on that subdomain.
So ... are stress-xx and stress-yy active variables on the lower-D elements? Do we have something trying to postprocess them that's assuming it's only getting called on a higher-D element?

Dear @roystgnr
yes, it is part-of-the-mesh-and-assembly-lower-D elements. you can see the mesh block at top of the issue.
regarding the 2nd part of the question, I have checked the input file again, the stresses variable are active on LD. Also, no restriction is set for calling the stress either fo LD or HD. Actually at this step I am trying to initialise the gavity in the model.

node.title: Boundary-restricted variables?
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I'm interested in modelling gas diffusion in metals and wanted to implement some new surface models which would use two coupled non-linear variables - one for the concentration of gas atoms in the bulk material and one for the surface coverage fraction of a monolayer of gas atoms adsorbed to the surface of the metal. The governing equations comprise 2 pdes and describe mass balance between adsorption/desorption between an external gas volume and the surface layer, and diffusion between the surface layer and the bulk concentration, and then onward diffusion downstream in the bulk only.
I was wondering what the best way to implement this scenario in moose would be? since I can't see anything that can act as a boundary restricted variable and, ideally, I'd prefer not to use an additional layer of cells for all external surfaces of any mesh trying to implement this surface model; spatially, the thickness of this layer would be one atom thick compared to mm or m thickness of the bulk material. Is there another way to think about this or are the extra cells unavoidable?

Hello
There are two ways to implement boundary restricted variables. The most straightforward is to create a lowerD block on the surface using this mesh generator:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator.html
then block-restrict a variable of a type that can support it (it will give you an error if not) to this block.
then you have to write kernels that make sense given the 2D support of the variable
Guillaume

node.title: Relaxation of jump value
node.bodyText:
All,
The value of my model jumps sharply at the interface and it requires a very small time step and  a very small mesh size to get a converged solution.  I am using a PenaltyInterfaceDiffusion type of an object at the interface.  I would like to ask if MOOSE has some apps to relax this jump: for example, gradually increase the jump value as a function of time? Please help. S. Thomas

Hello
I would make the parameter for the value of the jump controllable. Then you can use the Controls system to slowly increase the value through time.
To make a parameter controllable, you just have to make the parameter a Real and have
params.declareControllable("param_name");

in the validParams() of the object
Guillaume

Hi @styyokuda,
is the jump like what i explained here #26670 ?
I dont know your model enough, but in my case it is a 2D interface too.
Rahim
